Maybe later tonight we can discuss the origins of the need for privacy, and whether there exists a human drive for it at all :simple_smile:

<@U08EZP01H>: It's a different spectrum for every individual no? Freedom of expression sometimes blurs the line on a desire for privacy, but they're not mutually exclusive. If I sit high on freedom and high on privacy, it's probably because my views are dissenting of power. If I sit low on both, then it's probably because lolcatz

Yea, it's often about where that handoff is. I was trying to get even more meta though... I've been toying with a blog about whether our desire for privacy is actually just our fear of the unknown/less possible choices
It just seems obvious that when we talk about privacy we're really talking about safety.
I need a :coffee: before I can go that deep man :wink:
Maybe I had 1 too many.

"Our society is increasingly relying on the digitized, aggregated opinions of others to make decisions. We therefore designed and analyzed a large-scale randomized experiment on a social news aggregation Web site to investigate whether knowledge of such aggregates distorts decision-making." <http://www.sciencemag.org/content/341/6146/647.abstract>
2013 study on voting mechanism and herding

Privacy will naturally erode to a degree as global communications improve, but the ability to speak anonymously is something important to preserve IMO.  <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Federalist_Papers>

What is the process and approach to Mods?  
1.  Mods are extremely important - this can't be punted.  This is a separate and much more challening function than curation.
2.  Mods need to be in a position to ban users.  Yet this position must also be prevented from being used to control the conversation or extract value.
<@U08FW063C>: <http://go1dfish.me/blog/crypto-anarchy-social-aggregator-bitcoin-world-wide-ledger>  See collectives you could expand the idea to user filtering as well
Thanks

In a separate effort with a similar intent, we settled on the solution that identity by default should be non-anonymous, but that there should be the ability to generate both pseudo-anonymity and real anonymity for specific sub-communities.

<@U08DD8LNP>: IMHO, the Mod function provides a very wide array of values in addition to "pruning the conversation".  I think of it more like a host in a good salon - they frame the UI, the presence-absence of a wiki (or other features), the tone through policies and voice, etc.  Who gets to be a Mod, what they can do in general and then how they are themselves held accountable is where I'm most intrigued.
We are envisioning a network comprised of diverse clients.  UI control is not really an option, all those other policies are effectively filtering preferences

I take it that from your model, the version of a sub-community that I would see would be the "sum" of those comments not modded out by the individuals who I've chosen personally to "follow" as mods?  Thats a neat approach.
How does the community make their community look and feel like a place they want to be?
<@U08FW063C>: yeah pretty much, there is a very basic demo of the idea here: <http://dattnetwork.github.io/#/c/1NHy1SqQSeyEopKv3v1iTfx7sFdEiqocWb>
This might work nicely.  If you coupled it with a reward scheme for every user who is following a given "mod" you might find yourself with a large community of very good and very respected mods.

<@U08FW063C>: ideas from valME... mods can ban users for eternity or a set timeframe from posting (editorials and/or links) and/or commenting. additionally, if mods set the community up as private, they can only let certain users view. also, mods can ban domains or limit the number of links from a certain domain that can be submitted daily (across all users)

in this model a community is the sum of the content, and I agree that it’s not as strong of a community model as the subreddit model and that’s why I call them collectives to differentiate that.  It’s more about curation than trying to foster separate communities but they have a lot of similarity
So, no semantic separation?  Tricky.  IMHO, a big chunk of the value prop of reddit is the "feeling of community"
(Thanks for bringing me up to speed, by the way)
These are just my ideas btw, but they do seem to have fairly wide support here, it’s not the only way to do things
